page.title: 08FARMING AROUND CURDWORTH
page.content: CURDWORTH, 2 MILES BEYOND BIRMINGHAM'S EASTERN BOUNDARY IS SURROUNDED BY FLAT OPEN LAND WHICH IS INTENSIVELY FARMED. THE LESS FERTILE LAND TO THE SOUTH IS USED FOR GRAZING DAIRY AND BEEF CATTLE AND PASTURAGE FOR LOCAL RIDERS HORSES. THE REMAINING LAND, CULTIVATED BY SEVERAL LOCAL FARMERS, IS DEVOTED TO PRODUCING WHEAT AND BARLEY 60%, POTATOES, CABBAGES AND SPROUTS 18%, RAPE 6% AND HAY 16%. MODERN HIGHLY EFFICIENT METHODS FOR CROP SPRAYING, PLANTING AND HARVESTING USED. THE CEREAL CROPS ARE OVERWINTERED, THUS ENABLING HARVESTING DURING THE SUMMER MONTHS OF JULY AND AUGUST. THE SOIL BEING OF A SANDY NATURE NECESSITATES CONSIDERABLE ARTIFICIAL WATERING DURING DRY PERIODS. A PORTION OF THE FARMLAND WAS RECENTLY TAKEN FOR THE CONSTRUCTION OF THE M42 MOTORWAY BUT THE LAND LOST WAS LESS FERTILE NATURE.
